Sock, I've read everything I can find on Skyhook and from what I can gather, oalvarez has it pretty much covered.

A bit I might add:

The key to "getting" Skyhook is to accept that the valving can react so quickly that it adjusts as the wheel encounters each bump/irregularity, and the adjustment is done as the bump is being handled. That is the "active" part. The claim is that an adjustment from full-hard to full-soft takes 10 milliseconds, or 1/100th sec. The computer reads axle acceleration and position from sensors and tells the valves at each end what to do.

That's how it does what no passive system (e.g. current tech Ohlins for bikes) can do. Run along in full-soft and hit something very hard and the Skyhook valving firms up as the suspension handles that particular hit, preventing it bottoming out. Run along in full-hard and hit the same something and the valving softens so that you're not thrown out of the seat.

The point (for the computer) always being to keep the chassis as stable as possible within the limits of suspension travel and springing.

Within that, you have the four "modes", set by the rider as with the Ohlins set-up. Essentially, these seem to adjust the feel coming up from the road surface. Sport, you feel all the bumps; Touring, less so; Urban and Enduro, as little as possible.

Within each of these four modes, as stated above, you have the option to further refine the feel level. So when running in "Sport", you can choose from hard, medium or soft. Same in Touring, etc.

Whether Sport "soft" is the same as Touring "hard" etc, or whether all increments in Sport give more feel than Touring "hard", I don't think anybody has worked out at this point.

But even if there is overlap on the bump side, there is still the other aspect of Skyhook, which is its auto-adjusting the damping to resist chassis pitch under brakes and acceleration. How much it does this will be affected by what mode you are in.

Finally, there is the question of rear spring preload. It is not clear whether Skyhook offers the same 16 preload steps as the Ohlins, or whether it is just four steps (i.e. rider, plus luggage, plus pillion, plus luggage) similar to BMW. From early reports, is starting to look like it may be just the four.

I think there is no doubt the Skyhook takes away some control from the rider/owner. You can't take it to a suspension shop and change valving etc. Anything like that would happen via updating the software. And whatever you have set it to, the suspension makes up its own mind as to how appropriate your setting is for the conditions. But as long as Ducati/Sachs has done a good job with the software, that will be absolutely fine for most people.

BTW: Also not quite clear at this point, but at least one press report has claimed that within each mode, you can also set comp and rebound independently - e.g. comp to 'med' and rebound to 'soft' - if you want.

Hope that helps some.

### **Overall Scene Theme and Core Concept**  
**Scene Title:** *"Ducati Skyhook Suspension Development Lab"*  

**Core Concept:**  
A high-tech motorcycle suspension research lab where engineers, mechanics, and AI assistants collaborate to refine the Ducati Skyhook active damping system. The lab is a hybrid between a mechanical workshop, an electronics testing bay, and a data analysis hub, requiring constant coordination between human specialists and robotic agents.  

**Why Multi-Agent?**  
- Heavy suspension components require multiple agents for transport and assembly.  
- Sensor calibration and tuning demand simultaneous mechanical adjustments and software diagnostics.  
- Real-time data monitoring from bike test rigs necessitates parallel human-AI collaboration.  

---

### **Spatial Layout & Area Descriptions**  
The lab is divided into interconnected zones:  

1. **Suspension Assembly Bay** – A reinforced workbench area for assembling and disassembling shock absorbers, with hydraulic lifts and precision tools.  
2. **Electronics Calibration Station** – A clean, anti-static workspace for sensor tuning and firmware updates, surrounded by diagnostic monitors.  
3. **Dynamic Test Rig Chamber** – A soundproofed enclosure where a motorcycle chassis is mounted on a hydraulic shaker rig, simulating road conditions.  
4. **Data Analysis Hub** – A central workstation with multiple displays streaming telemetry from the test rig.  
5. **Parts & Storage Closet** – A cramped but meticulously organized storage area for spare components, fluids, and specialized tools.  
6. **Break & Discussion Corner** – A small lounge with a coffee machine, whiteboard, and scattered engineering notes.  

---

### **Detailed Area-by-Area Inventory**  

#### **1. Suspension Assembly Bay**  
**a. Anchor Furniture & Installations:**  
- **Heavy-Duty Hydraulic Workbench (250kg capacity)** – Adjustable height, with built-in clamps and oil-resistant matting.  
- **Overhead Chain Hoist (1-ton capacity)** – Used for lifting motorcycle chassis or suspension units.  
- **Tool Wall Rack** – Pegboard with precision torque wrenches, spanners, and impact drivers.  

**b. Key Interactive & Task-Relevant Objects:**  
- **Skyhook Prototype Shock Absorber (15kg, 40cm length)** – Partially disassembled, with visible valving mechanism.  
- **Damping Fluid Dispenser (5-liter reservoir)** – Adjustable flow rate, currently set to 10W oil.  
- **Laser Alignment Jig** – Used to ensure perfect shock mounting angle (±0.1° tolerance).  

**c. Functional Ambient Objects:**  
- **Bench Grinder (powered off, dusty)** – For smoothing metal burrs.  
- **Digital Calipers (battery low)** – Precise to 0.01mm.  
- **Parts Tray (half-filled with M6 bolts)** – Some greasy, some clean.  

**d. Background & Decorative Objects:**  
- **Faded Ducati Racing Poster (2018 season)** – Slightly torn at the corners.  
- **Coffee-Stained Workshop Manual (open to page 73: "Valve Timing Adjustments")**  
- **Dirty Rag (smelling of motor oil)** – Draped over a stool.  

---

#### **2. Electronics Calibration Station**  
**a. Anchor Furniture & Installations:**  
- **Anti-Static Workstation (grounded copper mat, wrist straps)** – For handling sensitive PCBs.  
- **Oscilloscope & Signal Generator** – Currently displaying suspension accelerometer waveforms.  

**b. Key Interactive & Task-Relevant Objects:**  
- **Skyhook Control Unit (firmware v2.1.7, flashing "CALIBRATION REQUIRED")** – Connected via USB to a diagnostic laptop.  
- **Sensor Test Rig (adjustable frequency actuator)** – Simulates road vibrations for calibration.  

**c. Functional Ambient Objects:**  
- **Label Maker (out of tape)** – Last label reads "DO NOT TOUCH – TESTING."  
- **Magnifying Lamp (LED flickering slightly)** – For inspecting circuit boards.  

**d. Background & Decorative Objects:**  
- **Stack of Old Firmware Chips (in a labeled "DEPRECATED" box)**  
- **Sticky Note ("Call Sachs re: valve response time")** – Yellow, peeling off.  

---

#### **3. Dynamic Test Rig Chamber**  
**a. Anchor Furniture & Installations:**  
- **Hydraulic Shaker Platform (500kg load limit)** – Currently holding a Ducati Panigale chassis.  
- **Safety Cage (interlocked door – rig halts if opened)** – Prevents accidental access during tests.  

**b. Key Interactive & Task-Relevant Objects:**  
- **Skyhook-Equipped Test Bike (sensors active, suspension in "TOUR/HARD" mode)** – Strapped into the rig.  
- **Emergency Stop Button (big red mushroom switch)** – Labelled "KILL TEST."  

**c. Functional Ambient Objects:**  
- **Noise-Canceling Headphones (hanging on a hook)** – For engineers monitoring tests.  
- **Vibration Log Printer (out of paper)** – Last printout shows erratic damping response.  

**d. Background & Decorative Objects:**  
- **"TEST IN PROGRESS" LED Sign (flashing amber)**  
- **Dusty Trophy ("Best Suspension Innovation 2022")** – On a high shelf.  

---

### **Scene Affordances & Embedded Potential**  

#### **Collaborative Transportation Affordances:**  
- **Hydraulic Workbench (250kg)** – Requires two agents to reposition safely.  
- **Motorcycle Chassis (180kg)** – Needs coordinated lifting via the chain hoist.  

#### **Reasoning & Tool-Use Affordances:**  
- **Attribute-Based Reasoning:** Among five damping fluid bottles, only **one** is labeled **"HIGH-VISCOSITY – FOR TESTING ONLY" (blue cap, handwritten, half-empty)**. Others are standard oils, but a decorative blue glass beaker nearby adds confusion.  
- **Compound Problem-Solving:** The **locked firmware terminal** (password-protected) requires finding a sticky note hidden under a coffee mug in the break area with the login credentials.  

---

### **Final Notes on Atmosphere**  
The lab hums with low-frequency vibrations from the test rig. The scent of motor oil mixes with ozone from electronics. The flickering LED of the magnifying lamp casts intermittent shadows, forcing agents to rely on precise perception. Every object has a purpose—or at least, the illusion of one.  

This environment is **ripe** for:  
- Multi-agent suspension tuning tasks.  
- Emergency protocol execution (e.g., stopping a runaway test).  
- Diagnostic troubleshooting under time pressure.  

**The stage is set. The agents will write the script.**
